headline: Jones to step down, ending historic era as House Speaker
summary: Maryland House Speaker Adrienne Jones's unexpected retirement may create policy uncertainty around her social justice priorities, potentially triggering public demonstrations if legislative direction changes under new leadership.

headline: State launches new strategy on chronic wasting disease ahead of deer season
summary: The Iowa DNR's 2025-2030 chronic wasting disease response plan addresses public health implications of a wildlife disease outbreak across 31 counties. The plan implements CDC recommendations for hunters to test deer meat, surveillance programs, voluntary population management, and hunter education initiatives to mitigate spread. It also monitors epizootic hemorrhagic disease pressures affecting deer populations.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: Health subsidies would continue for 3 years under Dem bill to be voted on in US Senate
summary: The Senate will vote next Thursday on a three-year extension of enhanced ACA marketplace tax credits to prevent average premium spikes of 26% (up to 175% in some regions) that would affect millions of families' health coverage; while a bipartisan House bill addresses short-term affordability and includes provisions for hospital billing transparency and pediatric cancer treatment access, Senate Democrats favor a clean extension without income caps, citing urgency before the December 15 open enrollment deadline and December 19 congressional recess.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: Most ACA marketplace users can’t afford potential increases, poll shows
summary: A KFF poll of 1,350 ACA marketplace enrollees found 60% cannot afford a $300 annual premium increase and 90% would struggle without marketplace access. Blame for potential $1,000 hikes falls on Trump (37%), congressional Republicans (33%), and Democrats (29%), varying sharply by party affiliation. Only 9% express strong confidence in Republicans addressing costs, reflecting public skepticism amid congressional deadlock over extending expiring enhanced tax credits. The survey signals healthcare affordability could become a major midterm election issue. With open enrollment closing December 15, legislative time is running short.

headline: McDonald holds strongest leads over GOP candidates in Michigan AG race, new polling shows
summary: A Public Policy Polling survey of 631 likely Michigan voters (margin of error 3.9%) shows Oakland County Prosecutor Karen McDonald leading potential Republican attorney general opponents Matt DePerno by 7 points and Kevin Kijewski by 5 points, while her Democratic primary rivals Eli Savit and Mark Totten hold narrower leads mostly within the margin of error, indicating McDonald has stronger general election positioning and greater name recognition among Democratic voters.

headline: Michigan Hmong leader released from ICE detention after push from federal and state lawmakers
summary: Lue Yang, a Hmong asylum seeker detained by ICE in July due to a 1997 burglary conviction, was released from federal custody following bipartisan legislative advocacy and a gubernatorial pardon. U.S. Rep. Tom Barrett (R) worked with federal agencies, while State Rep. Mai Xiong (D) and Gov. Gretchen Whitmer provided state-level support to pause his deportation to Laos. Despite his release, Yang’s immigration status remains unresolved and requires further court proceedings. The case highlights bipartisan cooperation on immigration enforcement and advocacy efforts to protect long-term residents from deportation. Advocates framed the release as a victory for immigrant communities amid broader concerns about detention and deportation policies.

headline: Delaware State Park Entry Fees Will Increase in 2026
summary: Delaware will raise state park fees in 2026 to increase dedicated revenue that funds 65% of park operating expenses, addressing rising maintenance costs from record visitation (7.4 million visits in 2024). This policy decision helps preserve services without requiring general fund budget cuts, representing a state budget strategy to support park operations through user fees rather than broader appropriations.

headline: Landry names new state revenue secretary following Nelson’s departure
summary: Governor Landry's appointment of Jarrod Coniglio as Revenue Secretary, following Richard Nelson's resignation, directly impacts Louisiana's state budget through oversight of tax collection and revenue forecasting, including implementation of historic tax reforms credited with attracting tens of billions in new investment.

headline: Feds’ immigration crackdown begins in Louisiana, with state leaders’ support
summary: Operation Catahoula Crunch launched in Louisiana on December 3, 2025, as part of the Trump administration's immigration enforcement surge, with state leaders and local law enforcement actively supporting ICE through detention agreements and threats to prosecute interferers; the ACLU has challenged a state anti-interference law in court, arguing it restricts free speech and advocacy; Louisiana currently holds 7,000-8,000 ICE detainees and opened a new 416-bed high-security facility, despite data showing 71.5% of detainees lack criminal convictions, undermining official claims of targeting "criminal illegal aliens."

headline: Poll: Virginians back mail voting and photo ID as partisan anxiety holds steady
summary: The Roanoke College Poll (Nov. 9-14, 2025; n=819; ±5.25% MOE) reveals Virginians strongly support both mail-in voting (65%) and photo ID laws (82%), while 53% oppose banning ballot harvesting. President Trump’s disapproval increased to 63% as Governor Youngkin’s approval held at 54% and Governor-elect Spanberger earned a 56% favorable rating. The political anxiety index registered 81.26, marking a complete partisan reversal from 2024 with Democrats now highly anxious and Republicans calm. Public trust in polling remains divided: 54% trust pollsters but 56% believe results are slanted, while 74% say the country is on the wrong track. The findings demonstrate persistent partisan polarization in evaluations of electoral policy, political leadership, and democratic institutions.

headline: Missouri schools could see new performance incentives under emerging proposal
summary: Missouri's School Modernization Task Force is developing a $50 million performance incentive program to reward districts for student achievement in early literacy, middle school math/language arts, and college/career readiness, with recommendations due to the full group in January under Gov. Mike Kehoe's executive order. A key policy debate centers on whether to provide larger bonuses when English-language learners, low-income students, and special education students hit targets—a proposal by state finance chief Kari Monsees to ensure equitable distribution that was questioned by Herzog Foundation's Chris Vas as potentially signaling some students are valued more than others. Economist Michael Podgursky warned that without weighted incentives, wealthier districts would disproportionately capture bonus funding, while the model is based on Tennessee's approach of doubling rewards for economically disadvantaged students. The framework follows Arizona's failed outcome-based program, which lawmakers eliminated in 2024 after funds flowed primarily to advantaged schools. The program would be funded through a separate state budget line item, with a committee to be formed to set precise achievement targets.

headline: Under Trump tax cuts, Utah won’t collect $500 million in income taxes in 2026, 2027
summary: Gov. Spencer Cox's $30.7 billion Utah budget proposal for 2026-2027 is slightly smaller than the current budget, reflecting a "flat year" as federal tax cuts reduce state revenue by $500 million. Following five years of state tax cuts totaling $1.4 billion annually, Cox is not recommending further income tax rate reductions. The proposal prioritizes $654.2 million for public education, $45 million for a new homeless campus, and $53.8 million for water infrastructure. It includes $290.3 million for state employee compensation increases and a $2.5 million child tax credit expansion. The budget balances continued tax relief with targeted investments amid constrained revenue growth.

headline: More Tennessee law enforcement agencies enter partnerships with ICE
summary: Tennessee law enforcement partnerships with ICE have risen to 54 agencies, including six recently added rural sheriff's departments and two state agencies (Department of Correction and Department of Safety and Homeland Security). Nineteen counties and the Tennessee Highway Patrol have adopted the expansive "task force" model authorizing immigration arrests during routine policing. Gov. Bill Lee and the General Assembly have allocated $5 million in grants to incentivize these 287(g) agreements. The federal government offers unprecedented reimbursements covering officer salaries, equipment, vehicles, and $500-$1,000 bonuses per officer for locating undocumented immigrants. Tennessee's rapid proliferation of these agreements ranks among the highest since President Trump's second term began.

headline: Tennessee comptroller foresees difficult budget year on horizon
summary: Tennessee faces a tight FY 2026-27 budget due to business tax cuts and expired federal stimulus, with the funding board projecting 2.25-2.35% growth ($450M new revenue) that lags behind 3% inflation, impairing purchasing power. While Finance Commissioner Bryson urged 1% departmental cuts, agencies requested major increases—$84M for Safety/Homeland Security and $85M for Corrections—as Republicans push to expand the $144M school voucher program. Democrats accuse GOP leadership of creating a "fiscal cliff" through $7.4B in business tax cuts over several years, while Republican officials defend their deliberate strategy. Despite maintaining a AAA bond rating, Moody"s analysts describe Tennessee"s economy as "treading water" amid tariff impacts and federal job cuts, with Comptroller Mumpower stating "prioritization is going to be the word of the year."

headline: How Idaho conforms to ‘big, beautiful’ bill amid budget woes will be central to 2026 Legislature
summary: Idaho faces a projected $600 million-$1 billion FY 2027 budget deficit, with $167 million from potential federal tax conformity; Lt. Gov. Bedke advocates tapping the $1.4 billion rainy day fund and blames the deficit on approving spending before setting revenue, while Gov. Little and legislative budget writers support 3% agency cuts and warn that using reserves for ongoing expenses is "a recipe for disaster," framing a key policy divide for the session.

headline: As ICE presence escalates in Minnesota, Somali leaders push back
summary: ICE has increased arrests in Minnesota under a targeted campaign ordered by President Trump, prompting Democratic state legislators and immigrant rights activists to verify hundreds of reports of ICE activity while combating high community anxiety and false alarms. State officials including Rep. Mohamud Noor and Sens. Omar Fateh and Zaynab Mohamed are distributing rights cards in Somali and Oromo languages, informing residents of constitutional protections against warrantless searches and self-incrimination. Activists accuse ICE of violating rights of immigrants and citizens, while facing government transparency issues as federal agencies do not release daily arrest statistics. The enforcement surge occurs amid President Trump's xenophobic remarks specifically targeting the Somali community.

headline: Gov. Morrisey needs to bring the guard home and stand up for West Virginia
summary: The article discusses the controversial deployment of West Virginia National Guard troops to Washington, D.C., a force sometimes used for civil unrest, but argues it was an unnecessary political stunt by Governor Morrisey as no crisis existed; it highlights a federal court ruling the deployment illegal and warns this sets a precedent for future contentious military deployments in other states, potentially involving civil unrest.

headline: People protest Deep South immigration crackdown as Gov. Reeves speaks at Madison restaurant
summary: Approximately 12 protesters demonstrated outside a Madison community meeting where Gov. Tate Reeves spoke, opposing Mississippi's collaboration with ICE through the 287(g) program and a two-month immigration crackdown in Louisiana and south Mississippi called "Operation Swamp Sweep" and "Catahoula Crunch." Demonstrators waved signs at passing traffic while organizers from Mississippi United and Adelante condemned the Trump administration's mass deportation campaign as intimidation harming immigrant families.

headline: A Month After Kauaʻi ICE Raid, Questions Linger
summary: Federal immigration enforcement detained 44 workers in Hawaii, none of whom sought asylum. Their employer, a local janitorial contractor, has faced prior federal scrutiny, indicating sustained enforcement focus on workplace violations. This demonstrates federal policy targeting both immigrant workers and their employers. The lack of asylum claims suggests either enforcement effectiveness or protection access barriers. The case exemplifies immigration enforcement impacts on Hawaii's labor market and immigrant community.
